newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: Ivorian land laws tighten title rules for farmers.
newsitem.headline: Ivorian land laws tighten title rules for farmers.

text.p: Ivory Coast is to establish new land laws aimed at clarifying title over property in an attempt to facilitate farm credit decisions and property transactions.
"The bill will remedy the lack of any real rural land ownership legislation in a mainly agricultural country," the government said in a statement after a cabinet meeting late on Thursday.
"The policy will be realistic in that it recognises common law rights...after an investigation and evidence of peaceful occupation," it added.
Under the new law, rural land would be considered separate from public, urban and protected forest categories.
As a first step, land certificates for individual or collective holders of recognised common law title would be issued before final registration of ownership, the statement said.
Ivorian nationals' existing rights to land would be unaffected and unattributed land would belong to the state. Applicants had three years to conform with new laws.

The bill shows the government's intention to clarify rural landownership and create a real market in property ownership with a mechanism for sale and rent, the statement said, pointing to requests from young farmers and financial organisations for such clarification.
Poorly defined land laws have been cited by local crop analysts as one reason for indiscriminate slash-and-burn farming with little attempt to achieve maximum crop yields from plots.

Ivory Coast's founding president Felix Houphouet-Boigny gave cocoa planters a common law right to land they planted and encouraged a wave of internal migration of aspiring cocoa farmers as well as newcomers from countries such as Burkina Faso to the north.
Cocoa production rose to make Ivory Coast the world's largest producer -- with about 40 percent of output. It notched up a record 1.2 million tonnes in the 1995/96 season.

Ivory Coast recently embarked on a policy of evicting coffee and cocoa farmers from dwindling protected forests, forcing foreign and non-local farmers out of encampments onto adjacent non-protected land.
The policy is aimed at preventing further destruction of forest cover essential for favourable climate for legal farms elsewhere, as well as promoting sustainable forestry.
It was also aimed at cutting Ivorian cocoa production to less than a million tonnes a year, to support world prices.

Ivory Coast classified certain forests as protected in 1973 but officials say many farmers settled in them after that and therefore have no common rights over land they have farmed. Many have been away from their homes for long periods.
Property developers have complained of land shortages and rising prices in growing urban areas such as the commercial capital, Abidjan. --Matthew Bunce, Abidjan newsroom + 225 21 90 90
